caseTitle: THE REPUBLIC v THE AUTOMATED FAST TRACKHIGH COURT ACCRAEX-P
summary: The Republic applied to the Supreme Court of Ghana for certiorari and prohibition orders to quash the rulings and proceedings of the Automated Fast Track High Court, Accra, presided over by Justice Gyeasayor, in Suit No. AL 109/06. The applicant challenged the courtâ€™s jurisdiction, alleging the transfer of the case to Justice Gyeasayor was clandestine and irregular. The Supreme Court dismissed the application as time-barred under Rule 62 of the Supreme Court Rules, C.I. 16 (as amended), which requires such applications to be filed within 90 days of the grounds arising. The court held the cause of action arose on 26th October 2006, when Justice Gyeasayor first exercised jurisdiction by granting default judgment, not in March 2008 when he refused to set aside proceedings. Despite arguments invoking interest of justice, the court found no basis to excuse the delay. The application was therefore dismissed.
citations: THE REPUBLIC VRS. HIGH COURT, KUMASI; EX-PARTE; MOBIL OIL (GHANA) LTD (HAGAN INTERESTED PARTY) [2005-6] SCGLR 312
Texano Africa Ltd. V. Bedu [1978] G.L.R 307
rationaleHighlights: Application dismissed as time-barred under Rule 62 of Supreme Court Rules (90-day limit)
The grounds for the application first arose on 26/10/2006 when jurisdiction was assumed, not on 10/03/2008
Distinguished from Mobil Oil case where cause of action arose from a refusal to recuse
Supervisory jurisdiction under Article 132 does not override statutory time limits without extension
Interest of justice argument rejected due to inordinate delay
confidenceNotes: High confidence; key dates, jurisdictional reasoning, and legal standards are clearly documented in the ruling.
